intro: Orthosia cassythoides, commonly known as the hairy false nettle, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Scrophulariaceae and is characterized by its slender, branching stems covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in clusters, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often have a slightly hairy texture. Orthosia cassythoides thrives in moist, disturbed soils and is often found in meadows and along stream banks.
